did.physdesc: 17.75 linear ft.(38 boxes) , 2 oversized papers (OP), and 3 bound volumes (BV)
did.abstract: Papers of Irish poet Joan McBreen, including correspondence, writings, photographs, audiovisual material and printed material.
did.repository: Emory UniversityManuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Special restrictions apply: Series 7: Use copies have not been made for all of the audiovisual series at this time. Researchers must contact MARBL in advance for access to these materials.
Series 11: Born digital materials are closed to researchers.

userestrict.head: Terms Governing Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: All requests subject to limitations noted in departmental policies on reproduction.

prefercite.head: Citation
prefercite.p: [after identification of item(s)], Joan McBreen papers, Manuscript, Archives, and Rare Book Library, Emory University.

processinfo.head: Processing
processinfo.p: Processed by Laura L. Carroll and Sarah Prince, July 2010.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Joan McBreen, Irish poet and teacher, was born in 1944 in Sligo, Ireland to Bernard and Patricia Collery. She attended Sion Hill Froebel College of Education and the National University of Ireland, and in 1970 married Joe McBreen. They have six children: Brian, Jody, Sarah, Helen, Peter, and Adrian. McBreen was a primary school teacher from 1966 to 1986, when she quit her position in order to pursue her career as a poet.

In 1990, McBreen published her first volume of poetry, The Wind Beyond the Wall. Subsequent volumes followed, including A Walled Garden in Moylough (1995), Winter in the Eye: New and Selected Poems (2003), and Heather Island (2009). McBreen earned a degree in Women's Studies from the University of Dublin in 1997, and her master's dissertation research focused on modern Irish women poets. This research informed her role as editor of The White Page: Twentieth-Century Irish Women Poets, an anthology she published in 1999. She has also edited The Watchful Heart: A New Generation of Irish Poets, Poems and Essays (2009), an anthology featuring the work of twenty-four Irish poets born in the last fifty years. In 2004, she released a CD entitled The Long Light on the Land-Selected Poems, which included McBreen reading her poetry to a background of traditional Irish music.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of the personal and literary papers of Joan McBreen from 1979-2007, documenting her career as a poet, anthology editor, and advocate for the increased awareness of Irish women poets. The papers include correspondence, writings by McBreen, writings by others, subject files, printed material, photographs, audiovisual material, and born digital material.

Much of the correspondence is to and from poets, friends, and her publishers, and is of both a personal and professional nature. The writings are primarily comprised of personal notebooks, collected and uncollected poetry, and dissertation notes and research. In addition, the series also contains a substantial amount of material relating to McBreen's editorial work on The White Page. The writings by others series is comprised of manuscripts and typescripts sent to McBreen, and are largely made up of individual poems and poetry collections, in addition to a small number of screen plays and essay drafts. Subject files document McBreen's involvement in numerous literary festivals and workshops, and also include some personal records, in addition to files on topics such as Irish politics and literary figures. Printed material consists of published material by McBreen, about McBreen, and general printed items collected by her. Photographs consist primarily of publicity photographs of McBreen and photos of individual contributors to The White Page. Audiovisual material consists solely of cassettes of recordings by McBreen's friend and fellow poet, Anne Kennedy.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into eight series: (1) Correspondence, (2) Writings, (3) Writings by others, (4) Subject files, (5) Printed material, (6) Photographs, (7) Audiovisual, and (8) Born digital material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series contains letters that McBreen wrote and received from 1986-2007. Much of the correspondence is of both a personal and professional nature; notable correspondents include poets and friends such as Rand Brandes, Eamon Grennan, Anne Kennedy, David Mason, Medbh McGuckian, Joan Newmann, and Tom MacIntyre. A significant amount of the correspondence includes faxes to and from McBreen's North American publishers, Robert and Lysa McDowell of Story Line Press. In addition, there is correspondence between McBreen and Salmon Poetry, her Irish publisher. Also included are many acceptance and rejection letters from literary magazines and invitations for readings and lectures, which document the growth of McBreen's career through the 1990s and 2000s. Correspondence related to the research and publication of The White Page can be found in Subseries 2.3: Edited works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series contains Joan McBreen's published and unpublished writings from 1986 to 2000 and is comprised of personal notebooks, collected and uncollected poetry, edited works, and other writings.
The notebook subseries (Subseries 2.1) includes notebooks that contain complete and partial poem manuscripts, literary notes and references, and personal reminders.

The poems subseries (Subseries 2.2) includes manuscript and typescript drafts of McBreen's collected and uncollected poetry. The collected poetry (subseries 2.2a) is arranged in chronological order by book and contains multiple copies of the same poems, providing insight into McBreen's meticulous process of writing and rewriting/revising her poetry in order to craft a final version. The subseries also contains a considerable number of McBreen's uncollected poems (2.2b), featuring both manuscripts and typescripts that are arranged here in alphabetical order.

McBreen's edited works (Subseries 2.3) consists of her editorial work on the poetry anthology, The White Page. This comprehensive study of contemporary Irish female poets features brief biographies and single poems by prominent poets, which are found in manuscript and typescript form in the individual author folders in the subseries. In addition, the author folders contain correspondence to and from McBreen, editorial corrections, and clippings. This subseries also contains general correspondence concerning the writing and publication of The White Page and a typescript draft of McBreen's editorial introduction to the anthology. Lastly, this subseries contains poem corrections, proof copies, contributor lists, and literary contact information for the 1999 publication.

The final subseries (2.4), titled "Other Writings" is primarily comprised of McBreen's dissertation work, which later became the foundational research for her anthology, The White Page. In addition, the subseries also includes McBreen's Irish to English translations of a small number of poems, an interview typescript, a book review, an essay submission, a letter to the editor, and a formal introduction of fellow Irish female poets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into four subseries: (2.1) Notebooks, (2.2) Poetry, (2.3) Edited works, and (2.4) Other writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The notebook subseries, spanning from the late 1980s to late 1990s, contains manuscript drafts of some of McBreen's collected and uncollected poems, literary notes and quotations, dated records of literary correspondence, and personal reminders. Although many of the notebooks have few writings, some allow insight into McBreen's creative writing process and her personal/academic literary interests.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The subseries includes manuscript and typescript drafts of McBreen's collected and uncollected poetry from 1986-1999. Of note to researchers is the thematic unity that runs throughout the entirety of the poetry subseries, centering on feelings of loss and renewal, familial memories and celebrations, local phenomena and politics, and the particularities of the Irish landscape. The collected poetry is arranged in chronological order by work, including McBreen's The Wind Beyond the Wall (1990), A Walled Garden in Moylough (1995), and Winter in the Eye: New and Selected Poems (2003). Many of the poems in this subseries have multiple drafts, providing researchers' insight into McBreen's meticulous process of writing and rewriting/revising her poetry in order to craft a final version.

This subseries also contains a considerable number of McBreen's uncollected poems, which were composed in large part during the seven year gap (1996-2002) between the publication of the poet's A Walled Garden in Moylough and Winter in the Eye. Some uncollected poems, however, were composed in the late 1980s and early 1990. Although McBreen offers no explicit rationale for how poems were selected for various collections, it remains clear that the poet subjected her uncollected poetry to equally rigorous revision processes, as many folders in this subseries contain uncollected poems that were written and revised multiple times. The uncollected poems are written in both manuscript and typescript forms, and are arranged here in alphabetical order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Organized into two sections: (2.2a) Collected poems and (2.2b) Uncollected poems.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged in chronological order by date of publication; individual poems within the work are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of McBreen's editorial work on the poetry anthology, The White Page: Twentieth-Century Irish Women Poets (1999). This comprehensive study of contemporary Irish female poets features brief biographies and single poems by prominent poets, which are found in manuscript and typescript form in the individual author folders in the subseries. In addition, the author folders, which are arranged in alphabetical order, contain correspondence between McBreen and the authors, demonstrating a vibrant and mutually supportive literary network of Irish female poets. The subseries also includes editorial corrections, clippings about various poets, proof copies of the anthology, contributor lists, literary contact information, and general correspondence concerning the writing and publication of The White Page. Importantly, the subseries also holds a typescript draft of McBreen's editorial introduction to the anthology, an essay that first originated while the poet wrote her master's dissertation on Irish female poets. Photographs of The White Page contributors including publicity photos, portraits, and personal snapshots donated to McBreen may be found in Series 6: Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The other writings subseries is comprised primarily of McBreen's dissertation work, which later became the foundational research for her anthology, The White Page. In addition, the subseries also includes McBreen's Irish to English translations of a small number of poems, an interview typescript, a book review, an essay submission, a doctoral dissertation proposal, and a formal introduction of fellow Irish female poets. This series, in addition to the poet's editorial role in the publication of The White Page, demonstrates McBreen's active involvement in promoting and sustaining a community of Irish women poets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of writings by other authors sent to Joan McBreen from 1985 to 2002. Although the writings are largely made up of individual poems and poetry collections, the series also includes a small number of screen plays and essay drafts. As many of these writings include correspondence between McBreen and other authors, notations and cross-references have been provided throughout the series listings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by author, then in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of subject files covering a variety of topics from circa 1980s to 2003, and document Joan McBreen's involvement in numerous literary endeavors such as the Galway Writer's Workshop, Listowel Writer's Week, and Yeats International Summer School. The series also consists of personal records, including address books, datebooks, and scrapbooks in which McBreen compiled clippings related to various topics of interest. McBreen also kept subject files on topics such as Irish politics and literary figures, including Eavan Boland, Seamus Heaney, Padraic Fallon, Ted Hughes, and George MacBeth. Finally, this series includes McBreen's files relating to her time as a student at the University College Dublin, such as correspondence and course material. Her dissertation can be found in Subseries 2.4: Other writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series is comprised of printed material by Joan McBreen, about Joan McBreen, and general printed items from 1985-2007. Although poems published between 1987 and 1999 make up the largest part of the printed material by McBreen, she did publish one letter to the editor of an unidentified newspaper concerning the value of modern poetry. In contrast to the narrow focus of the printed material by McBreen, the printed material about McBreen consists of a variety of published resources pertaining to the author, including articles, programs, announcements, promotional material, and reviews of many of her published poetry collections. Lastly, the general printed material, spanning from 1978-2007, is comprised of magazine articles, brochures, flyers, newsletters, newspaper clippings, poetry inserts, programs, travel materials, and numerous periodicals. Of note to researchers is McBreen's extensive collection of articles and clippings, which demonstrate an acute concern with the success of fellow Irish poets, Irish history, and with various papal scandals in Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of three categories of photographs, taken from 1979-2000: photos of Joan McBreen, photos of others, and photos of individual contributors to The White Page. Photographs of McBreen include portraits, publicity photos, and snapshots with literary colleagues, family, and friends. Photographs of others include many photos of McBreen's husband, children, and extended family, as well as various colleagues and poetry workshop participants. Lastly, photographs of The White Page contributors consist of publicity photos, portraits, and personal snapshots donated to McBreen for their use in the anthology on Irish women's poetry.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Photographs of McBreen are arranged in chronological order; photographs of individual contributors to The White Page and other people and places are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This series contains sound recordings collected by McBreen and consist primarily of recordings of her friend, poet Anne Kennedy, from 1988-1995.
